neofriends.siteDescription: my favourite is reading through sadgrls manifesto and new old web pages. sadgrl has a bunch of fun projects on the go so be sure to check them out. a fun site to explore and get lost in.
a whimsical collection of shrines, dreams and other nostalgic stuff. my favourite is to read the meomoirs which recount memories of a web of yesterday.
a wonderfully crafted homepage full of flashing glittery graphics.
another whimsically styled homepage with shrines, graphics, and other web goodies to explore and download.
self described symphonic metal & midi romance. packed full of homemade music and short stories to explore.
complete with an esoteric design, a homepage full of poems, original graphics and essasy.
cleverly put together! love the punk show bathrooms page.

ownWeb.author: victoriadrake
ownWeb.siteDescription: victoria explores the joys of creating your own personal website.

this page is part of an online course run through the hyperlink acadamy. displayed here are the results of the participants lovingly hand crafted projects from the course. some interesting sites to explore.

interestingArticles.author: Pop Punk & Linguistics
interestingArticles.siteDescription: a  linguistics professors analysis of the american pop punk accent. great read.

interestingArticles.author: The Rise & Fall of Internet Art Communities
interestingArticles.siteName: The Rise & Fall of Internet Art Communities
interestingArticles.siteDescription: a deep dive into the rise and fall of art communities of the early web.

interestingArticles.author: david siegel
interestingArticles.siteName: the web is ruined and i ruined it
interestingArticles.siteDescription: a very deep dive into a time in the 90s where the web changed for better or worse. read it and decided for yourself.

digitalGardens.author: Tanya Basu
digitalGardens.siteName: Digital gardens let you cultivate your own little bit of the internet
digitalGardens.siteDescription: a look into people who are creating and cultivating their own digital gardens online.

digitalGardens.author: Joel Hooks
digitalGardens.siteName: my blog is a digital garden, not a blog
digitalGardens.siteDescription: joel takes us through how his blog is not in fact a blog, but a digital garden. it's different. really.

digitalGardens.author: Maggie Appleton
digitalGardens.siteDescription: maggie has put together a great collection of gardeners who are publicly tending theri digital notes on the interwebs. also has a great number of digital garden resources

digitalGardens.author: Tom Critchlow
digitalGardens.siteDescription: tom takes us through the his thoughts and process for building personal wikis to tend to personal knowledge

digitalGardens.author: Chris Aldrich
digitalGardens.siteDescription: list of all wiki related posts, have not explored all of them yet.

digitalGardens.author: rosie campbell
digitalGardens.siteDescription: rosie uses obsidian publish to create her digital garden. public notes and knowledge base featuring articles, quotes, advice and recipes.

linkDirectories.author: kicks
linkDirectories.siteDescription: the final heartbeats of our beloved www. a hand curated list of links in the style of old yahoo. lots of interesting homepages to get lost in.
a web directory and listing for all kinds of websites
not quite a link directory, however it is a great little collection of interesting links to mostly personal homepages.
an archive featuring a huge collection of fandom type content. i don't even know where to begin with this one.
a webring collecting hand-crafted wikis and portfolios. designer, developer focused. 157 listens with some gems in there.
a webring collecting hand-crafted wikis and portfolios. designer, developer focused. 157 listings with some gems in there.

linkDirectories.author: john december
linkDirectories.siteDescription: a rather large, long running, website. includes a hand curated (i think) web directory. wow. so many links to all corners of the world wide web. let me know if you find anything awesome in there.
a decent directory of handmade webpages. some really interesting and clever pages in there.

linkDirectories.author: waylon531
linkDirectories.siteDescription: a decently sized directory with like 98 categories? so many pages to explore!

webLogs.author: laura kalbag
webLogs.siteDescription: laura is a designer who has published a book covering accessibility. she is one part of the small tech foundation. her blog is full of some great interesting stuff.

webLogs.author: patrick collison
webLogs.siteDescription: really simple blog with an interesting range topics making up the content. patrick is very thoughtful. not your typical dev blog...

webLogs.author: sirodoht
webLogs.siteDescription: a few interesting articles, the most interesting to me was the one on ideal blog platforms and the other on the mataroa webring. materoa seems to be a simple blogging engine the author has created.

webLogs.author: scott hanselman
webLogs.siteDescription: looks like an old blogger template. lots of great articles on various topics. i enjoy their yearly developer and power user tool lists.

webLogs.author: elliot
webLogs.siteDescription: a really interesting wild take on how to hand craft your homepage!

webLogs.author: dima
webLogs.siteDescription: a few posts on various developer things. my fav was the 10 things i've learned while building this website, touches on some 11ty topics

webLogs.author: tom hackshaw
webLogs.siteDescription: not sure if i should categorise this one as a blog as it's so much more. a manifesto (which is awesome by the way), a living wiki, a bookshelf (yay) as well as a blog.

webLogs.author: dennis mai
webLogs.siteDescription: a nice looking website where dennis shares a bunch of his projects, webrings and a selection of articles.

webLogs.author: paul graham
webLogs.siteDescription: simple looking website with a heap of content. some really interesting essays amongst a bunch of other stuff.

coolSites.siteDescription: album information, largest music database online. huge market place for music reselling, love it for tracking down vinyl.

huge lyrics database. used to be just rap music, but now offers all genres. use it for checking out what the actualy lyrics are after singing something completely wrong for days after listening to a song.
have used imdb for decades to check out movie infomation, cross reference actresses and check to see if that was actually them in that movie.
an online record store and music community for fans to discover, connect with, and directly support the artists making awesome music.

manifestoSites.siteName: ten commandments of the small internet
manifestoSites.siteDescription: a grassroots internet movement called "the small Internet" is afoot. here are ten commandments that cheapskates would like to see largely obeyed on the small internet.
"I miss the internet of the early 1990's."

manifestoSites.siteName: what i learned about the internet by creating my own website
manifestoSites.siteDescription: here are some things cheapskates learned about the internet by creating their own website.
we, the people of the internet, have the power to restore it to its former glory.
web 1.0 design nostalgia. like all nostalgia, it's bullshit.

manifestoSites.siteName: seven reasons for having a personal website
manifestoSites.siteDescription: there are at least seven reasons you should have a personal website.
in big cultural concepts like music or fashion, things have a way of coming around full circle.
"ever since I visited my first web site (via a slow modem to a library BBS running a text-based web browser), i have been ceaselessly pondering the nature of the web."

manifestoSites.siteName: the missing hit and the open web
manifestoSites.siteDescription: if it doesn't appear in google's search results, does it really exist?

a dozen years ago, the web started to reshape itself around major companies like google. we can understand the genesis of today’s algorithmic arms race against the tech titans just by looking at a single character.

manifestoSites.siteName: the modern web is becoming an unsuable. user-hostile wasteland
manifestoSites.siteDescription: the question is: at which point do we reach the breaking point?

manifestoSites.siteName: autonomy online: a case for the indieweb
manifestoSites.siteDescription: there is an alternative to corporate bubbles online — it’s called the indieweb. build your own personal websites, control your online presence, and learn on your own terms.
"i prefer websites that are built with simple html, minimal css, and no javascript for read-only web experiences."
the personal website is a somewhat mysterious animal that lives mostly unobserved in the jungle of the internet

manifestoSites.siteName: zeronet and the future of the internet
manifestoSites.siteDescription: until recently, the conventional wisdom was that the internet is beyond the control of governments. how naive the conventional wisdom sometimes is.

manifestoSites.siteName: tell hn: i miss the old internet
manifestoSites.siteDescription: "this is more of a rant i guess. hackernews provides a text box, that's close enough for me."
